fields.description:
SourceTree crashed on startup, and requested the log to be sent to you, so here goes.

Some additional info:
* After the crash, I re-started SourceTree, and it opened without a hitch.
* I had four tabs open with Mercurial repositories (like I've had for months now)
Crashed while trying to switch from one repository to another by double-click in the repo navigation pane
Was pretty close to sign-on, so it may have been related to system load and/or service availability.

I made some minor changes on my master branch that I wanted to commit in another branch. I create the new branch and try to make commit but there were no files to commit, still SourceTree showed me there were 2 pending files then I went back to master and back to working copy and it crashed.
Would be nice to have a checkbox to automatically delete a stash when you apply it back on one of your branches

fields.description:
SourceTree does not start ANY MergeTool - unless which one I configure (BeyondCompare, KSIff3, TortoiseMerge). I even tried to configure KDiff3 as "Custom" MergeTool - without any success ...

What happens when starting a MergeTool from Sourcetree:
* Infobox pops up, saying external mergeTools is gonna be launched
* The cursor changes to a dotted circle
* The cursor changes back to normal
* That's it - nothing else :-(

Hint:
Within my Sourcecode-Folder a set of Files named basename_LOCAL*, basename_REMOTE*, basename_BASE* and basename_BACKUP* are created. Those files are not removed after MergeTool startup failure
fields.summary: SourceTree does not open any MergeTool

fields.description: I have no idea what happened in fact

The disk folder in the left-side bookmark bar is purely visual clutter that makes it harder to read the salient information. Practically speaking, unless you stick your project folders off the drive root, you never see enough of it to be useful without making the sidebar excessively wide.

Picture example: !SourceTreeSideBar.jpg|thumbnail!

Could the disk folder be removed from the sidebar and the full path shown on hover instead?

Hi,
I have just installed and started using the Windows desktop version of SourceTree and I've noticed that the mouse pointer seems to be 'stuck' at vertical arrows - it is a single vertical line with an arrow at each end of the line. I was expecting it to use the standard Windows 'arrow pointer' for most of the window.

Ah! Just found that after I restarted the app the mouse pointer goes to what I'd expect it to see.

I think this might be a bug in the installer. During the install process I got most of the way through the various screens (sorry, cannot remember which one) before the mouse pointer changed to the 'vertical arrows'. At the end of the install process I chose to start SourceTree straight away. I'm guessing that the initial execution of the program inherited this display from the install process.

Regards,
Dave
fields.summary: Mouse pointer sticks at vertical arrows, does not use Windows default pointer

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:

1. Have uncommitted changes in submodule.
2. Pop-up window appears:

!submodulecheck.PNG|thumbnail!

3. Click open, and a freeze window appears, and it is totally non-functional. The only way to get rid of the window is to close the repository tab, and reopening it:

!commithang.PNG|thumbnail!

This can also be reproduced by doing the following:
# Create a new repository A in SourceTree
# Add another repository B as a Submodule
# Commit the above change in repository A
# Change a file in your local folder of repository B
# Change a file in repository A
# Try to commit the changed file in repo A
# A warning appears that submodule B has uncommitted changes
# Press 'Open' in the warning message
# A Commit windows opens, which does not show any files, and does not respond when the user clicks 'Commit' or 'Cancel'
 !commithang.PNG|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Submodule commit window totally does not function.

When the last session of SourceTree was minimized when closed, the next time we will start SourceTree it will still be minimized. My problem is that similarly, when I start SourceTree (e.g. SourceTree -f .... log) when another session of SourceTree is already running and is minimized, SourceTree will also stay minimized. I typically start these sessions with the -f option from another program, and it's not always obvious to the users of my program that SourceTree has been started when it is minimized. It would be nice if it could be restored to non-minimized in that case, regardless of its previous state. If not automatically, at least through a command-line option.

The Help->Report Bug in Sourcetree menu takes you to the projects Kanban Board https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/SRCTREEWIN. Bug report link could probably link to a simpler page with better performance.

- Observe a commit where the time should be 15:35, is now 03:35:

French:

fields.description:
My workflow uses IntelliJ, mvn from the command line and SourceTree for git.  

Anyway, when I've completed a user story in IntelliJ I then switch IntelliJ into power save mode  (to stop it scanning the file system) and run "mvn clean install" to perform a full compile before checking in.

Generally SourceTree behaves itself whlie I do this, but I have a suspicion that it too uses filesystem watchers and so is also trying to sync up with the files that are being modified by the mvn command line.

It would be nice to feature in SourceTree similar to IntelliJ's "Power save" mode, to temporarily switch off file system syncing.  (And I'd suggest using this same term, given that so many developers are likely to be using IntelliJ).

As a refinement, perhaps there might be an "auto powersave mode", whereby switching focus away from SourceTree would disable its filesystem watching, ie so that it only does this when it has focus.

Obviously, this feature idea applies also to SourceTree on the mac.
fields.summary: Provide a "Power Save" mode to avoid cpu burn/battery drain/glitches when performing other work.

Just opening sourcetree, got the crashed dialog which brought me here.
Crashed on startup. See attached log.
SourceTree seems to crash on the initial start after the computer boots up.  I tend to restart my computer daily and the crash only occurs on the first time I open SourceTree right after a restart.
fields.summary: Crashes on initial launch every day.

fields.description: Starting with either 1.6.16 or 1.6.17, I get an 8-second delay every time I start SourceTree.

I was using git bash and staged some files. I switched over to SourceTree, opened the branch and saw that my staged files were not showing up in the list so I hit F5 to refresh. When that didn't work, I unchecked "Staged files" to see if I could refresh somehow and then SourceTree crashed. I've attached my log

I'm using the DisplayLink driver for my 7" USB monitor. After update the SourceTree, the sourcetree's main window does not display any information. It just white space.
I've searched all possible solutions and I found that after uninstalling DisplayLink Driver, the sourcetree window show the information. 

Thanks,
Allen.

It's confusion if the branch graph colors change with each commit. Especially if using Git Flow with it's fixed 5 branches, it would be really helpful UX wise if each branch type would always get the same color assigned.

Thanks for looking into this feature request.
fields.summary: Keep fixed branch graph colors for Git Flow repos

fields.description: SourceTree already supports searching for commits by their hash including its shorter representation, it also supports detecting of LONG hashes in commit messages (only!). It would be a nice feature if SourceTree would make links to commits from short hashes too, much like the online bitbucket(/github) clients do.
fields.summary: Detect shorter hashes in commit messages

fields.description: It crashed when I launched it. attached is the log.

fields.summary: Merge Conflict should show original as a 3rd block

fields.description: If I clone a particular Branch, usually "master", it would be very desirable if that branch name was "sticky" in the Pull dialog, and elsewhere wherever a Branch input is required.  Needing to "Refresh," and then locate "master" in a long drop-down is really quite a PITA.
fields.summary: Make Remote Branch Sticky (Pull Dialog, possibly elsewhere)

fields.description: This would the the same functionality as the git log --no-merges command.
fields.summary: Support the ability to exclude merge messages in the log and search displays

fields.description:
I get this Authenticate window every so often popping up somewhere, asking me for a password. The username is readonly, cannot be changed, and is incorrect for the server it requires a password for.

It doesn't matter if I type in bollocks or my actual password, or just cancel the window. The window will always pop up a few hours later. It also doesn't matter if I set up ST to use my system Git (2.4.5) or the embedded Git (1.9.5).

What's more, everything just works fine. I can use the very same server in Sourcetree absolutely fine.

In short:
1) The username cannot be changed
2) Even if it could, this popup will reappear no matter what

fields.description:
when you mark a unstaged file to include it in the staged files view all the directory tree were folded.
So you cant mark mark more than a few files at the same time.
You have to expand all the tree again, mark the next few files and so on.

The Problem is: Sometimes you mark a file, but in this moment sourcetree foldes the tree
and you mark complete parts of the tree..and has to be undone manually!

So please let the tree open, just move marked files out of the tree and don't rebuild the complete tree in folded state!

Anothe Problem: whne there are many file it tooks a long time to rebuild the tree, so you have to wait many seconds for SourceTree is available again!
fields.summary: update of files foldes directory tree

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:

1. Open a random branch
2. Click 'File status' 
3. Switch from default 'Pending files, sorted by file status' to 'All'
4. Set Staged/Unstaged files view from 'flat list, single column' to 'Tree view'
5. Enter the search box and start searching

This causes SourceTree to hang for a while (my repository's size is 1.21MB with quite a number of files, folders and subfolders.)

A user even mentioned that the memory footprint increased dramatically from approximately 150 MB to 3.5 GB in a short time in a repository with this details:

* total number of sources: 26.121
* total number of directories: 1915
* total size: 333.71 MB
* folder with most sources in one folder: 2471 sources
* largest source: 326,34 KB
fields.summary: SourceTree hangs when searching in TreeView mode

fields.description:
I edited two files (on different branch each):

On branch "master", I edited this file:

!masterbranch.PNG|thumbnail!

On branch "third", I edited this file:

!theotherbranch.PNG|thumbnail!

Then I merged the branches together, and the merge commit now has two parents.

However, if we check the merge commit, it only shows the diff in relation to the first parent:

!firstparent.PNG|thumbnail!

It does not show the diff in relation to the merge parent - it should show the changes of the file belonging to branch "master", but it does not:

!mergeparent.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Log view involving a merge commit with two parents only able to show the diff of the first parent; the diff of the merge parent does not display.

fields.description:
I use Stash to create, and branch repositories.  I use SourceTree to maintain these repositories, including tagging important commits, such as releases.  When using the git command line tool to investigate my repositories using 'git ls-remote <repo_url>', I get back the expected response, except that my tags are duplicated in the following fashion:

a71364f2645fc8e27cb079f30cdf81aec38c4895    HEAD
a71364f2645fc8e27cb079f30cdf81aec38c4895    refs/heads/develop
7a8731e3b7d49af653ff67a7c35c928453471839    refs/heads/feature/oozie_fuoll
a71364f2645fc8e27cb079f30cdf81aec38c4895    refs/heads/master
e34fc078e27e129f5241bdf85226629db3c3b5e9    refs/heads/release/rel1
53d29f94fc28d47b118ecc578bec337229abb8c2    refs/tags/1.0.0
29484edfeaf42d1cb277714509fa55e643c2dfe8    refs/tags/1.0.0^{}

The last entry is the one I'm concerned with.  I used SourceTree to add a tag with the text '1.0.0', and it created that tag, and one with the text '1.0.0^{}'.  Further, I investigated the reference numbers, and the tag with the extra symbols is actually pointed to the correct commit.  The other commit reference is not listed.

For now, I can do automation of command-line interaction with my repos via tag by parsing the ^{}, throwing away the bogus tag, and continuing, but that does not seem like the desirable behavior for this system.

Exact steps:
Create a repository in Stash.
Clone it in SourceTree, add filed, and do initial commit.
In SourceTree, add a tag (e.g.: '1.0.0').
On the command line, use git to get the tags using 'git ls-remote <repo_url>'
fields.summary: Duplicate tag entries with appended pattern

fields.description:
Just opened SourceTree for Windows this morning and it crashed. I had just recently installed the latest update. Also I use git. Log attached.

UPDATE: I was able to open it just fine when I tried again.

Branches on remotes (on Stash or otherwise) remain visible forever. Remotely deleted branches will never dissappear. This is confusing for developer, because it looks like a remote branche still exists, but when trying to switch to one and execute a pull, you'll get an error saying the branche no longer exists on the remote.

Please remove branches from the GUI when they no longer exist on the remote.

Seems like a reasonably high priority issue to me, since this is corrupting the development workflow, most notably when working in feature-branches.

Switching to different branches changes the Pull count (commits behind) in the toolbar, but the number does not reflect the real value (which is shown in branch tree).

Inquire attached Problem Steps Recording.
In Log/History view, when scrolled to a highlighted commit/tag/branch, after clicking on column width resizer, the current focus is lost, i.e. view jumps to the top (commit).
fields.summary: Clcking on column width resizer causes focus loss

fields.description:
When global git config sets to use rebase for tracked branches as true:

$ git config -l
$ branch.*branch-name*.rebase = true

The checkbox function in Tools > Options > "Use rebase instead of merge by default for tracked branches" will not have any effect even if it is unchecked to not use rebase.

SourceTree should provide some indication that rebase is used even though it is not requested in the setting would be helpful or alternatively maybe a means to force merge to be used.
fields.summary: When global git config sets to use rebase for tracked branches as true,  "Use rebase instead of merge by default for tracked branches" function in SourceTree will not have any effect.

it might be better giving a 1 to 3 secs response time?
fields.summary: create new repo repo on cursor/specific location instead of very bottom

fields.description:
how to reproduce

1. open any file
2. made changes
3. in "unstaged files" select "..." -> "Discard file"
4. "Discard Changes" dialog is open but it's empty

[I suspect this is the same as SRCTREEWIN-3028]

Setup: Unstaged view in tree mode, multiple files in unstaged view, nothing in staged view.

1. Click top-level checkbox to stage everything
2. As soon as files move to staged view, click that top-level checkbox to unstage everything
3. As soon as files move back to unstaged view, shift-click to multi-select files (since the first file should already be selected)

This has fairly consistently, but not 100% consistently, crashed. Timing seems relevant. Guessing a race condition between the interaction and updating the views.

fields.description:
When I enter a commit message with non-ASCII characters (German umlaut, Greek, ...) those characters are displayed correctly in the input field.

In the log list an log details, however, those characters are displayed as their utf-8 octets.

The text highlighted in the attached screen shot should read

"Test für Umlaute u.ä." and "Δηλφοί"
fields.summary: Commit messages with UTF-8 not displayed correctly

fields.description:
Im using ST with github. Trying to open submodule (see screen) ST crashes.
This started happen after last update.

When cloning a repository from Stash using Source tree for Windows, source tree does not compare the size of the remote repo before beginning the close operation. In the event of low disk space and a large repository to be cloned, source tree can spend upwards of 10-15 minutes cloning before realizing that the space available is insufficient.

Suggestion: Check for sufficient free space before starting any downloading.
fields.summary: Compare clone size with free space

fields.description: When using the embedded git ( 1.9.5 ) I can see branches and work with sourcetree. When using system git ( 2.4.5 ) I do not see them, hence can not work with sourcetree
fields.summary: Sourcetree does not work with git 2.4.5

fields.description:
Because of long history, multiple branches and tags, filling of pull down list for "Jump to" button takes a lot of time even on a second try (tens of seconds for the first call, seconds for consequent).
Usually I have exact commit hash to jump to and the first entry "Commit..." is more than enough for me.
Is it possible to defer load of full tags/branches list and show the list immediately with "Commit..." entry only?

I just downloaded the latest version of SourceTree and I get the following error in the log when I try to open a Pull Request- the UI crashes.
{noformat}
2015-07-16T13:10:03: Fatal error: 
System.NullReferenceException: Object reference not set to an instance of an object.

2015-07-16T13:10:03: Stack trace: 
   at SourceTree.Repo.RepoHelper.CreatePullRequest(Repository repo, RepositoryRemoteProjectLink link, String remoteBranch, String commitSHA) in C:\projects\bitbucket.org\atlassian\sourcetreewin\Repo\RepoHelper.cs:line 843

{noformat}

Steps to Reproduce:
# Right click on any Branch
# Select "Create a Pull Request..."
#* Expected Behavior: User would be taken to the Stash page with information populated
#* Actual Behavior: Crash Message

Steps tried:
* Restarting Stash
* Checking Remote Details settings- everything was right initially
* Using "Repository -> Create Pull Request" 
** This does not cause a SourceTree Crash, but it does not work- it continuously sends me back to the  "Create Pull Request" Screen.
* Changed the visible panes from "Tree View" to "Flat List"

Also, please note that I *am* able to create a pull request using the Stash UI.
